G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as this matter involves a civil action for monetary damages exceeding $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Suffolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred within Suffolk County.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 90, § 14, "[n]o person shall open a door on a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without interfering with the movement of other traffic, including bicyclists."

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: The violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14 constitutes evidence of negligence under well-established Massachusetts law.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the effect of violating a statute like G.L. c. 138, § 69 and states the general Massachusetts rule that such a violation is not negligence per se but is only “some evidence” of negligence. While the case is about § 69, the court frames the principle broadly—“violation of a statute … is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant’s negligence”—which directly supports the proposition that violation of a motor vehicle statute such as G.L. c. 90, § 14 constitutes evidence (but not conclusive proof) of negligence under Massachusetts law.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant further violated the general duty of reasonable care owed to all other users of the roadway.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss negligence and a duty to use reasonable care, but only in the context of the defendant’s potential duties as a homeowner/general contractor toward workers on his property and his statutory obligations. It does not address or recognize any separate ‘general duty of reasonable care owed to all other users of the roadway,’ nor does it involve roadway or traffic circumstances. Thus the case does not support the specific roadway-duty proposition claimed.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … [T]he plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them as either homeowner or general contractor, or because of any failure to warn of any purported defect on his property.”

Coombes v. Florio, 450 Mass. 182 (2007).proposition: Defendant further violated the general duty of reasonable care owed to all other users of the roadway.
Coombes v. Florio, 450 Mass. 182 (2007).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is only the brief per curiam disposition reversing summary judgment and remanding, without any discussion of duties owed to roadway users or the general duty of reasonable care. While Coombes v. Florio as a whole involves duty questions, the text supplied here does not show that the court articulated or applied a general roadway duty standard. On the basis of this limited text alone, the opinion cannot be said to support the stated proposition.
Coombes v. Florio, 450 Mass. 182 (2007).relevant_excerpt:
The judgment of the Superior Court granting the defendant’s motion for summary judgment is reversed. The case is remanded to the Superior Court for further proceedings.

So ordered.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligent act directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries, losses, and damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements of negligence in general terms (duty, breach, damage, and causal relation) and holds only that the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care and that the negligence claim may proceed to a jury. The court does not decide that the defendant’s negligent act directly and proximately caused the plaintiff’s injuries; causation is expressly left as a factual question for trial. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about direct and proximate causation being established.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. ... We generally consider the latter three questions ... to be the special province of the jury. ... We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care."

Gonsalves v. Commonwealth, 440 Mass. 603.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a driver may be held liable for “dooring” accidents when opening a car door creates a foreseeable risk of harm to bicyclists.
Gonsalves v. Commonwealth, 440 Mass. 603.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns workers’ compensation benefits under Massachusetts General Laws c. 152, §§ 31 and 35C, in the context of an asbestos-related occupational disease and retirement. It does not address motor vehicle liability, bicyclists, or the duty of care when opening a car door (“dooring”). Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about driver liability for dooring accidents.
Gonsalves v. Commonwealth, 440 Mass. 603.relevant_excerpt: Since enacted in St. 1911, c. 751, the Massachusetts workers’ compensation scheme has been conceived as a mechanism by which workers can recover a portion of that income that they are kept from earning because of an injury suffered while working. … We interpret G. L. c. 152, §§ 31 and 35C, an integral part of the workers’ compensation scheme, in light of these principles.

O\u2019Malley v. Putnam Safe Deposit Vau.raw_text: O’Malley v. Putnam Safe Deposit Vaults, Inc., 17 Mass. App. Ct. 332 (1983)
O\u2019Malley v. Putnam Safe Deposit Vau.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a driver may be held liable for “dooring” accidents when opening a car door creates a foreseeable risk of harm to bicyclists.
O\u2019Malley v. Putnam Safe Deposit Vau.case_name: O'MALLEY v. Putnam Safe Deposit Vaults, Inc.
O\u2019Malley v. Putnam Safe Deposit Vau.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns liability of a safe deposit company for an employee’s conversion of gold coins from a customer’s safe deposit box. It does not involve motor vehicles, bicyclists, or any ‘dooring’ fact pattern, nor does it discuss duties owed by drivers when opening car doors. Therefore it provides no authority on Massachusetts law regarding driver liability for dooring accidents.
O\u2019Malley v. Putnam Safe Deposit Vau.relevant_excerpt: “With reference to banks or safe deposit companies, there is in Massachusetts no similar recognition of a public policy imposing liability. Foster v. Essex Bank, 17 Mass. at 510. We think Foster is controlling. … Accordingly, we conclude that the duty of due care under counts two or three, whether the action be denominated contract or tort, … is that of a prudent person operating a safe deposit business.”

Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.raw_text: Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640 (1961)
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was unreasonable under the circumstances and constitutes negligence per se.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.case_name: Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats the defendant’s bar as owing a duty of reasonable care under the circumstances, not negligence per se. The court upholds the jury’s ability to find negligence based on foreseeability of harm and a statutory violation as evidence of negligence, but expressly notes that violation of G.L. c. 138, § 69 is ‘not conclusive evidence’ and is only something the jury may consider. Thus, the case supports a standard negligence/foreseeability analysis, not that the conduct constitutes negligence per se.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.relevant_excerpt: “The judge in substance charged that if they believed the testimony that O’Brien was under the influence of liquor they might consider the statute; that violation of the statute was not conclusive evidence, but might be considered on the issue… The substance of the requirement to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm was stated. The circumstances did call for special care in respect of O’Brien’s conduct… On these facts a finding of the defendant’s negligence was warranted.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s failure to exercise due care when opening his vehicle door.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This case concerns a college’s liability for a sexual assault on campus and focuses on issues of proximate cause and foreseeability in the context of campus security, not a defendant’s duty of care when opening a vehicle door. The quoted dissent discusses whether the rape was within the foreseeable risk of various security lapses (unsecured gate, unlocked refectory), and ultimately finds lack of proximate cause; it does not involve motor vehicles, door-opening, or analogous facts. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition about injuries being foreseeable consequences of negligently opening a car door.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[ ] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982)… The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.… Similarly, the jury would not have been warranted in finding that a prudent person in the defendants’ circumstances would have locked the refectory to prevent rape.”}

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff’s comparative fault, if any, was minimal and does not bar recovery under G.L. c. 231, § 85, because Defendant’s negligence was greater than that of Plaintiff.

Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.proposition: Plaintiff’s comparative fault, if any, was minimal and does not bar recovery under G.L. c. 231, § 85, because Defendant’s negligence was greater than that of Plaintiff.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The case directly interprets G.L. c. 231, § 85 and explains that in negligence actions a plaintiff’s contributory negligence only bars recovery if it is greater than the negligence of the defendants. The court holds that even though the plaintiff unreasonably used a known-defective product (barring warranty recovery), that conduct does not, as a matter of law, bar negligence recovery; instead, under § 85 the jury must compare relative fault, and the plaintiff is barred only if more than 50% at fault. That aligns with the proposition that the plaintiff’s (here, 49%) fault does not bar recovery where the defendant’s negligence is greater.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought… The plaintiff's conduct… does not bar recovery completely unless the plaintiff is more than fifty per cent responsible for his or her own injuries…. Under the negligence count, the plaintiff is not barred unless his negligence is greater than the negligence of the persons against whom recovery is sought.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered physical injuries, emotional distress, lost wages, medical expenses, property damage, and pain and suffering.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The case is about recoverability of emotional distress damages in negligence, particularly requiring physical harm for negligent infliction of emotional distress and addressing prenatal injury and DES causation. It does not discuss, list, or approve any standard catalogue of damages such as lost wages, medical expenses, property damage, or pain and suffering flowing from negligence. Instead, it deals with whether plaintiffs without present physical injury or with in‑utero injury have any cause of action at all. It therefore does not support the broad proposition that, as a proximate result of negligence, a plaintiff suffered the enumerated categories of damages.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt:
"In summary, we hold that a plaintiff who alleges that she suffered injury in utero as a result of her mother's ingestion of a drug and that, but for the defendant's negligence, her mother would not have ingested that drug, has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted under Massachusetts law."

"In summary, we should that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causation; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
